Comment: Hopefully, the Dems have figured out that focusing on Trump's incompetence and chaos is far more useful in driving up his disapproval than are the Dems' go-to messages about his meanness and illegal conduct.  A lot of Americans are willing to give a pass to a president who they believe is capable and achieving results.  It's failings in areas that matter to them such as the economy that will turn them off.    If the public sees Trump as being inept, then they will start piling on with the rest of it.  But it really needs to start with the job failures, not the ethical ones.
Author: I405CA

Comment: The good news, say Democratic leaders and top party strategists wrapping their heads around what Donald Trump’s next 45 months will mean, is that there is no shortage of actual impacts to talk about – and that’s before the market turmoil has had the effect on prices or jobs that they expect.  The bad news, they say: the speed and thoroughness out of the White House keeps scrambling their already frantic efforts to fight back.  Every bad Trump poll number has top Democratic operatives and officials wondering if they’re actually seeing the country start to move their way again or if they’re just talking themselves into seeing that.  It’s what Illinois Rep. Sean Casten, first elected in the anti-Trump wave of 2018, [calls a progression from apathy to fear to anger to action](https://www.cnn.com/2025/04/28/politics/democratic-resistance-learning-curve/index.html?utm_medium=social&utm_source=reddit).  Now: “I think we’re moving from incoherent to directed anger,” Casten said, then added his own stage direction: “He says, optimistically.”
Author: cnn
